ense. So now my questions are this:

ations evolve in the usual sense?

ance on the problem, and the vector

not

tegy

f-adapted SDs are better than leaving

tness landscapes: note that the sphere

=99d like to see a sweep across different

uced.

>

ose in the ES community,
> *assume* that self-adapting mutation rates are b=
eneficial, but no one ever

ow that. I=E2=80=99m not blaming you:
> of course this is not your communit=
y. But I=E2=80=99ve had the same conversation

=E2=80=A6I find it a bit odd and frustrating: it=E2=80=99s like an urban
> =

mark their algorithms on noisy

>

ged landscapes of
> the long-term, because noise can help you cross a valle=
y (by temporarily
> making the valley seem more fit).
>
>
>
>> 3) If CMA-ES=
 is self-adapting its mutation rate in a way that helps: why?
>> My paper l=
ays out intuitive reasons for why we should expect mutation rates
>> to evo=
lve to be low and hurt long-term performance (because evolution is
>> focus=
ing on the short-term average fitness, not the long-term average
>> fitness=
). So why doesn=E2=80=99t this reasoning apply to CMA-ES?
>
>
>

also my understanding of how it works in tradition ES. But I

uals in CMA-ES are mutated versions of their parents. I think they

reshly drawn from the learned distributions. And I don=E2=80=99t think

ffspring are kept, but are only used to update the learned distributions.
>=
> But as I said, my knowledge of CMA-ES sis fuzzy. Partly because I don=E2=
=80=99t
>> understand it perfectly, it=E2=80=99s hard for me to see if ther=
e is some mechanism
>> that allows self-adaptation to work well.
>>
>
> In =
the previous email I was mostly talking about ES. You are right that
> CMA-=
ES works differently. The mean individual is calculated using weighted
> re=
combination. I don't understand CMA-ES perfectly either, so you've got me
>=
 thinking. I think now that CMA-ES does not exactly use self-adaptation in
=
> the normal sense, since it uses something called cumulative step adaptati=
on
> (CSA), also known as cumulative path length control. CSA does not use =
local
> mutation steps, but a record of fading mutation steps, known as evo=
lution
> path or search path, which carries information about the relation =
between
> single steps.
>
> I read that this evolution path can improve the=
 adaptation and search
> procedure remarkably. Do you think it can be seen =
as a way to mitigate the
> problem of long-term adaptation?
>
>
> I don=E2=
=80=99t know, because I don=E2=80=99t understand it enough. But at least it=
 sounds
> like it is trying to incorporate the effect of mutation rates ove=
r multiple
> generations, which is already an attempt to take a longer-view=
. My
> instincts tell me, however, that if it averages over N steps/generat=
ions,
> and N is small (vs. the overall number of generations in a run), it=
 will
> still underperform a high-fixed rate. As N goes towards the total n=
umber of
> generations in the run, it will do better=E2=80=A6but that=E2=80=
=99s only because it=E2=80=99s
> getting rid of self-adaptation and switchi=
ng towards fixed mutation rates.
>
>
> So fitness does impact which SDs sur=
vive? That does sound like
>> self-adaptation, making me skeptical about wh=
ether it really works.
>
>
> Yes, in self-adaptive ES (not CMA-ES), fitness=
 does impact which SDs
> survive and selection is deterministic / rank-base=
d.
>
>
>
>
>> Thanks for the clarification. It=E2=80=99s an interesting, im=
portant question and
>> I=E2=80=99m glad we=E2=80=99re trying to get to the=
 bottom of it.
>>
>
> In summary, I now think that self-adaptive ES might n=
ot perform very well
> for long-term adaptation, while CSA (which is not th=
e same as self-adaptive
> mutation rates) is a way to make the algorithm pe=
rform better.
>
>
> Great. This is how these conversations always go! I kee=
p waiting for
> someone to say =E2=80=9Coh, here=E2=80=99s the thing you do=
n=E2=80=99t understand that explains it
> all=E2=80=A6=E2=80=9D, but instea=
d most people end up agreeing that  (a) self-adaptation
> doesn=E2=80=99t w=
ork, (b) what they were calling self-adapatation is something
> else, or (c=
) stick to the belief that there is lots of evidence that
> self-adaptation=
 does work, but they don=E2=80=99t know of any specific papers, and
> tell =
me I should just go =E2=80=9Cread all the old literature=E2=80=9D. I=E2=80=
=99m glad that you
> are in the (a) and (b) camp! I find the (c) camp a bit=
 frustrating, partly
> because I haven=E2=80=99t had the time to undertake =
that quest myself=E2=80=A6though I
> think I know what the result will be. =
:0)
>
> Thanks for the interesting discussion.
>
> Best,
> Jeff
